What is one difference between SaltStack and Ansible?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Ansible is agentless and uses SSH to connect with target systems.
SaltSTack uses a minion-master model (agents are called minions) and SSH to connect with target systems.
This makes Options A, B, and C incorrect.
D is correct by elemination

Selected Answer: D
What is a minion in SaltStack?
The salt-minion is a single process that sits on machines to be managed by Salt. It can either operate as a stand-alone daemon which accepts commands locally via 'salt-call' or it can connect back to a master and receive commands remotely.
Ansible playbooks are written in YAML.

Selected Answer: D
Ansible uses SSH so disregard Telnet options.
D correct, 100%
given answer is correct

choices.B: SaltStack uses an API proxy agent to program Cisco boxes in agent mode, whereas Ansible uses a Telnet connection.
choices.C: SaltStack uses SSH to interact with Cisco devices, whereas Ansible uses an event bus.
choices.D: SaltStack is constructed with minion, whereas Ansible is constructed with YAML.
choices.A: SaltStack uses the Ansible agent on the box, whereas Ansible uses a Telnet server on the box.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
In HA, When the active WLC fails, the standby WLC takes over. Mobility peers connected to the primary WLC must be manually configured to use the MAC address for the secondary WLC under their mobility setup. To avoid the hustle, we automate this process by using mobility MACs. Mobility MAC is a virtual MAC address shared between the primary and secondary WLC in an HA setup. Mobility MAC ensures that the other mobility peers are handled by the secondary WLC upon a failure in the active WLC.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/technotes/8-7/High_Availability_DG.html
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/catalyst-9800-series-wireless-controllers/213913-building-mobility-tunnels-on-catalyst-98.html

questions.question_text: A customer has a pair of Cisco 5520 WLCs set up in an SSO cluster to manage all APs. Guest traffic is anchored to a Cisco 3504 WLC located in a DMZ. Which action is needed to ensure that the EoIP tunnel remains in an UP state in the event of failover on the SSO cluster?

questions.question_text:
Which configuration filters out DOT1X messages in the format shown below from being sent toward Syslog server 10.15.20.33?

Nov 20 13:47:32/553 %DOT1X-5-FAIL:Authentication failed for client (e04f.438e.de4f) on interface Gi1/0/1 AudtiSessionID 0A0B50A5000004543910739E

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The syslog message "Nov 20 13:47:32/553 %DOT1X-5-FAIL:Authentication failed for client (e04f.438e.de4f) on interface Gi1/0/1 AudtiSessionID 0A0B50A5000004543910739E," contains the following fields:

Nov 20 13:47:32/553 --> Timestamp (date & time)
%DOT1X --> Facility Code (always start with the '%' sign)
5 --> Severity (0-7)
FAIL --> mnemonics (categorizes the event within the facility code)
"Authentication failed for client (e04f.438e.de4f) on interface Gi1/0/1 AudtiSessionID 0A0B50A5000004543910739E" --> message-text (condition of the vent that triggered the system message)
"drops" keyword ---> used to drop the message that matches the pattern specified by the discriminator
"logging host 10.15.20.33 discriminator DOT1X" ---> assigns the discriminator with a Syslog server @ 10.15.20.33

DOT1X-5-FAIL:
facility: dot1x
severity:5
mnemonic:fail
seq no:timestamp: %facility-severity-MNEMONIC:description

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct one
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A. logging discriminator DOT1X facility drops DOT1X
logging host 10.15.20.33 discriminator DOT1X

Explanation:

The logging discriminator command creates a discriminator named DOT1X.
The facility drops DOT1X part specifies that messages with a facility that includes DOT1X should be dropped.
The logging host 10.15.20.33 discriminator DOT1X command sends log messages to the Syslog server at 10.15.20.33, but only those that do not match the discriminator criteria (i.e., excluding DOT1X messages).

Selected Answer: A
logging discriminator DOT1X facility drops DOT1X: This command creates a logging discriminator named "DOT1X" and configures it to drop syslog messages with the facility "DOT1X". So, any syslog messages with the facility "DOT1X" will be dropped (not logged).

logging host 10.15.20.33 discriminator DOT1X: This command specifies that syslog messages that match the criteria defined by the discriminator "DOT1X" are sent to the syslog server at the IP address 10.15.20.33. So, syslog messages that pass through the "DOT1X" discriminator (i.e., not dropped based on the first command) will be sent to the specified syslog server.

Selected Answer: A
Logging discriminator discr-name [ [facility] [mnemonics] [msg-body] { drops string | includes string } ] [ severity { drops sev-num | includes sev-num } ] [ rate-limit msglimit ]

Selected Answer: A
filters out facility=DOT1X messages and drops them

Selected Answer: A
it should be A

I think that the correct answer should be A).
logging discriminator DOT1X facility drops DOT1X
logging host 10.15.20.33 discriminator DOT1X

Selected Answer: A
Given answer is wrong. The message body doesn't contain "DOT1X". However the logging facility is "DOT1X" so A seems good.
https://youtu.be/Lbb7vlQoGt0?feature=shared&t=154
